attributes.title: Assessing Attitudes toward the Affordable Care Act

q1.value: Assessing Attitudes toward the Affordable Care Act

q5.value: The Russell Sage Foundation provided funding for this research (94-17-01).

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This research is a series of survey experiments which are themselves part of a broader project on Americans' attitudes toward the Affordable Care Act (ACA) and proposals to repeal and replace it. This specific element of the project is a set of survey experiments embedded in a single survey instrument conducted via Survey Sampling International in late September 2017 which aim to identify different experimental manipulations which do or do not shift health policy-related attitudes. Existing scholarship has provided a range of explanations for Americans' attitudes toward the ACA, including those emphasizing political partisanship, self-interest, trust in government, attitudes toward racial/ethnic groups, and responsiveness to elite framing. We seek to test these various possibilities experimentally, through specific experiments which attempt to operationalize these differing hypotheses.

q16.value: Each of the experimental manipulations corresponds to a different hypothesis and so merits different potential moderators. One experiment considers whether attitudes toward health policy display a status quo bias, in which proposals described as changes from the status quo will be penalized relative to proposals described as a return to a prior status quo. We will first 1) estimate the overall effect of this randomization. We will then estimate 2) whether this effect varies by respondents' levels of information (measured via education and media consumption). We will also examine the effects by 3) self-reported health status (having a pre-existing condition and self-reported health status), as well as 4) attitudes toward the parties and Obama (measured via the Obama feeling thermometer, partisanship, and 2016 vote choice). A second experiment instead examines the role of partisan priming. Specifically, some respondents were randomly assigned to report their attitudes toward the ACA after being asked for their 2016 candidate preference and approval/disapproval of Donald Trump, while for others, the order of those questions was reversed. Again, we will first 1) estimate the overall effects of this randomization. We will then analyze 2) differences by partisanship (using the Trump and Obama feeling thermometers as well as party ID and 2016 vote choice) and 3) information (using education and media consumption). In another experiment, we seek to understand the role of attitudes and cues related to ethnic/racial groups in shaping ACA-related attitudes. Our survey explained that the ACA had extended insurance to approximately 17 million Americans, and randomly assigned respondents to read an additional clause indicating that 7 million of those people were Hispanic or African American or not. Here, we propose to 1) analyze the overall effects, and then analyze the effects for non-Hispanic white respondents broken out by their 2) political partisanship (party ID, 2016 self-reported vote choice, and Trump feeling thermometer) and 3) attitudes toward these groups, as expressed by the difference in their feeling thermometer ratings of these groups relative to Whites. Following Hetherington (2006), we also propose to examine the results 4) by levels of governmental trust. A fourth experiment, also building off Hetherington (2006), considers the role of low government trust in shaping ACA attitudes. Some respondents received an ideological anti-ACA message while others saw a low-trust anti-ACA message and still others saw no message at all. Here, we will consider the 1) overall effects as well as 2) the effects broken out by respondents' self-reported social trust and governmental trust. We will also 3) examine the results by partisanship, measured via 2016 vote choice and 7-category party ID. A fifth experiment considers the effect of labeling a measure as "repealing the ACA." Specifically, it either does or does not label the September 2017 Graham-Cassidy proposal explicitly as repealing the Affordable Care Act. We will examine its 1) overall effects as well as 2) its effects by information (education and media consumption) and 3) by partisanship. The sixth experiment is highly similar to the fifth: in a list of potential priorities related to the ACA, some respondents saw "repealing Obamacare" while others saw "repealing the Affordable Care Act." We will examine 1) the overall effect as well as 2) the effect by political partisanship and the Obama feeling thermometer and also 3) by information (measured via education and media consumption) and 4) racial attitudes (measured via feeling thermometers). The seventh experiment is also a list of ranked priorities in which respondents could rank the importance of providing health care for "all Americans" or for "poor Americans." Here, too, we will analyze the 1) overall effect as well as 2) the effect by the Trump feeling thermometer and by 3) self-reported income and 4) racial affect. The eighth experiment examined the same ranking of priorities, but instead involved either including an item that read "reducing spending on Medicaid" or else read "reducing spending on Medicaid, which provides health insurance to older and low-income Americans." Here, we will examine the overall effects as well as those broken out 2) by racial attitudes, 3) self-interest (measured via age and income), and 4) political partisanship.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses, we will initially conduct balance tests to examine whether there are important demographic variables which are imbalanced for any experiment. We then intend to specify appropriate generalized linear models which condition on 1) basic demographic covariates, being sure to include 2) pre-treatment covariates which are imbalanced. While our primary results will emerge from these models, we will also estimate basic differences in means. We will estimate moderation effects by subsetting the data as appropriate.

While our primary results will emerge from these models, we will also estimate basic differences in means. We will estimate moderation effects by subsetting the data as appropriate.

attributes.title: The Impacts of a Randomized Housing Policy in Uruguay

q1.value: The Impacts of a Randomized Housing Policy in Uruguay

q2.value: Craig McIntosh | Felipe Monestier | Rafael Piñeiro | Fernando Rosenblatt | Guadalupe Tuñón

q5.value: We want to acknowledge support from Fondo María Viñas (fmv_1_2014_1_1003689), Agencia Nacional de Investigación e Innovación (ANII) of Uruguay.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: We will measure the impact of a housing program run by the Uruguayan government called "Compra de Vivienda Nueva" (CVN). This program began in 2008, and offers lower income families the opportunity to buy an apartment unit in a new building by providing them with generous mortgage subsidies. Because of the large income transfer provided by the program there was substantial excess demand, and the government allocated access by conducting lotteries for each new building within the pool of eligible applicants. We observe the outcome of 126 separate building/lotteries, and can use both survey and institutional data to track how the lives of the beneficiaries are impacted as they move.

q16.value: Hypotheses H1: Our main hypothesis is that homeownership positively affects the probability of participating in local elections. H2: The change in political participation will be larger when the subsidy transfer to the household is larger. H3: Controlling for the subsidy amount, households that move across neighborhoods in which the local voting rates have increased more will see larger increases in participation. H4. Controlling for subsidy amount, the larger is the increase in property prices between the old and the new neighborhood, the larger will be the increase in participation. H5. Controlling for subsidy amount and local voting rate differences, the farther that households move in geographic distance, the smaller (more negative) will be the change in voting rates. This is due to a ‘social dislocation’ effect of moving away from prior networks, other things held equal. Heterogeneous Treatment Effects We anticipate that the treatment will generate heterogeneous treatment effects in a number of well-defined dimensions. Individual variation: 1. Subsidy amounts. 2. Distance moved. 3. Child age at moving. Neighborhood-level variation: 4. Change in local-level political participation. 5. Change in socio-economic status.

q17.value: We present two measurement strategies, one to measure an Intention to Treat that handles the two-sided non-compliance in a manner that is directly experimental, and will be biased towards zero by it. The second is an instrumental variables method for measuring the Local Average Treatment Effect of an additional year of exposure to the program. In both cases our analysis uses cross-sectional data subsequent to the lottery.

q27.value: Ministry of Housing, Territorial Planning and Environment of Uruguay

attributes.title: Household Upgrade Decisions in Off-Grid Solar Services [Part 1 of study]

q1.value: Household Upgrade Decisions in Off-Grid Solar Services [Part 1 of study]

q5.value: We thank the Tata Center for Technology and Design at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for its generous support of this project. , Data will be collected with support from the Busara Center for Behavioral Economics in Nairobi, Kenya.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This project uses a conjoint analysis survey to elicit heterogeneous household preferences for off-grid solar technologies and services in rural Kenya. Understanding and describing these preferences is critical to off-grid energy business models. This research examines preferences beyond basic lighting to higher-margin products, such as TVs. Companies are selling solar home systems that provide enough electricity for lighting services, cellphone charging, and television. Beyond basic services such as lighting and charging, the market for “higher-margin products” such as fans and TVs is expected to grow to 7 million fans and 15 million TVs by 2020. This project aims to understand how price and quality characteristics influence decisions about upgrading solar home systems to allow for more higher-margin products. Further, this project examines household preferences for information about solar products.

q16.value: Substantial attention has focused on the purchase of technologies such as solar home systems (Bensch et al., 2018) while simultaneously calling for a focus on end uses of solar (e.g., appliances). This project aims to bridge these two by examining appliances used on or compatible with solar home systems. Overwhelmingly, studies point to cost (Bensch et al., 2018), income thresholds (Gertler et al., 2016), and credit constraints (Urpelainen and Yoon, 2015) as key inputs into the household decision process for solar purchases. This study examines the multidimensional nature of quality, including technical quality indicators, service quality, and payment options. Based on the previous literature our preliminary hypotheses are the following. H1: Households are more likely to upgrade their solar home system if they are offered financing in a pay-as-you-go daily rate. H2: Upgrades are more preferable if they are compatible with the grid. H3: Households will upgrade with companies they knew of before the purchase. H4: Households prefer to speak with someone in person if there is a problem. H5: Households prefer to purchase appliances from someone who visits them at home.

q17.value: To test these hypotheses we propose to use a conjoint analysis survey. Conjoint analysis surveys “ask respondents to choose from or rate hypothetical profiles that combine multiple attributes, enabling researchers to estimate the relative influence of each attribute value on the resulting choice or rating” (Hainmueller et al., 2014, p. 2). This approach allows for joint effect of different attributes on an overall judgment (Rao, 2014). Paired conjoint analysis has been shown to come closest to observed behavior (Hainmueller et al., 2015) . Data will be analyzed using a binomial logistic regression model (binary choice outcome) to determine the effect of different attributes on the stated choice preference of respondents. In addition to binomial logistic regression, we will also explore using the cjoint package in R (Oliveros and Schuster, 2018).

q19.value: 360 respondents, each responding to 6-8 choice sets per conjoint (n = 2160 - 2280)

q27.value: Researchers, Busara Center for Behavioral Economics

attributes.title: Never Again: The Political Lessons of Repression

q1.value: Never Again: The Political Lessons of Repression

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: What political lessons do victims of extreme repression learn and pass on to their children? This project explores how the personal experience of repression may change the political attitudes of survivors and their descendants in two distinct and competing ways. First, experiences of repression could engender empathy toward other victims, making survivors of repression (and their descendants) more supportive of oppressed outgroups. On the other hand, experiences of repression could heighten levels of fear such that the future security of the group becomes paramount. This could make these individuals less supportive of other repressed groups, if they believe these groups constitute some type of threat. In this study, we explore these two divergent effects in the context of the Jewish experience of the Holocaust and their commitment to the abstract principle of `never again.' Specifically, we use a survey experiment among American Jews (including survivors, descendants, and those with no family connection to the Holocaust), priming empathy or threat considerations and then measuring support for US acceptance of Syrian refugees, and other outgroup political attitudes.

q16.value: The Empathy Hypothesis: All else equal, Holocaust survivors and their descendants will be more supportive of other vulnerable outgroups than non-survivor populations (both Jewish and not). The Threat Hypothesis: All else equal, Holocaust survivors and their descendants will be less supportive of other vulnerable outgroups than non-survivor populations (both Jewish and not). Direct Trauma Hypothesis: Holocaust survivors will be less supportive of other vulnerable outgroups than non-survivor populations (both Jewish and not), but their descendants will be more supportive than both survivors and non-Jews, because they did not directly experience trauma. Group Exposure Hypothesis: All Jews, irrespective of familial exposure to the Holocaust respond similarly to outgroups (as compared to non-Jews), because Jewish group identity could lead all Jews to feel the psychological impact of the Holocaust. The Priming Hypothesis: Reminders of empathy or threat can shift attitudes toward vulnerable outgroups,such that: Empathy primes increase support for vulnerable outgroups and threat primes decrease support for vulnerable outgroups.

q17.value: We test these hypotheses with a survey experiment. In the survey, respondents answer a battery of questions on potential moderating variables prior to treatment. We then randomly expose respondents to a control or manipulation condition, and then ask additional questions on key dependent variables. We survey individuals from four populations living in the United States: Holocaust survivors, children and grandchildren of survivors, Jews with no family connection to the Holocaust, and non-Jews.

registration_responses.q1: Never Again: The Political Lessons of Repression

attributes.title: The Influence of Social Reference Groups on Behavioral Interventions to Reduce Absenteeism and Dropout from Vocational Education

q1.value: The Influence of Social Reference Groups on Behavioral Interventions to Reduce Absenteeism and Dropout from Vocational Education

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Dropout and absence is a large problem in vocational training in Denmark which has large societal costs. Many policy reforms have sought to address the problem, e,g., by implementing admission thresholds, restructuring the general program, setting up performance measures for the different educations and supporting the creation of more internships (The Danish Government 2014; Munk et al. 2015). However, few of these reforms directly address the motivation and goals of the students themselves, which has been argued to be a large part of their absence and dropout in vocational educations in Denmark (Katznelson and Brown 2011). In this study we seek to use Mental Contrasting with Implementation Intensions (MCII) as a cost-efficient, psychological way of addressing student absence and dropout from vocational training in Denmark. MCII has been shown to affect goal-directed behavior in various fields and settings, especially in the educational setting (Duckworth et al. 2013; Oettingen et al. 2013; Kizilcec and Cohen 2017). The idea is that it is not always enough to have goals. People need to develop a sense of feasibility of the goal – an expectation of successful goal striving – and a commitment to these goals. However, the goals may still not succeed in creating goal-directed behavior, because we have a tendency not to consider the impeding reality when constructing the goals. MCII seeks to address these pitfalls in creating goal-directed behavior and succeeding in reaching the goals by instructing people to think about both their goals, why they would like to meet them, which obstacles they will probably face along the way and to plan strategies to overcome these. In a way, MCII is a structured way of thinking about goals, a self-regulation strategy, that may more effectively result in goal fulfillment (Oettingen et al. 2013), making it a type of wise psychological intervention (Walton 2014). Furthermore, we will investigate the influence of social image among adolescents when they attend an education. It is well known that adolescents are more susceptible to peer influence than other age groups and they should also still be under the influence of their parents (Steinberg and Monahan 2007; Steinberg 2014). It has been argued that social image is an important influence when adolescents make educational decisions (Bursztyn and Jensen 2015, 2017). We argue that this social image might change with different reference groups, such that adolescents react differently when they are thinking about their parents as opposed to thinking about their peers as reference groups when making decisions. Therefore, our MCII treatment group is divided into two treatment groups where the students are either presented with questions about their parents’ or their peers’ recognition and a question on how important this reference groups’ recognition is to them before being asked the standard MCII questions. Therefore, we are priming the students to think of either their parents or peers and the students’ own perceptions of how much recognition they would get from these reference groups if they completed their basic education. Lastly, we will examine whether the students’ self-control (Tangney et al. 2004) will moderate the effect of MCII on student absence and dropout. Self-control is thought to moderate the effects of MCII, since people high on self-control may already have a tendency to follow through on plans, while people low on self-control may need some help, especially on forming and sticking to the if-then plans (Oettingen et al. 2013). Therefore, we expect that self-control will moderate the effect of MCII such that the effect is largest among students with low self-control.

q16.value: Primary hypothesis: H1: MCII will reduce absenteeism of all participating students on average Secondary hypotheses: H2: Priming students to think about peers will reduce absence (relative to priming to think about parents) the more recognition from peers they perceive they will get. H3: The more positive recognition students perceive they will get from peers, the more will the effect of MCII be moderated by priming students to think about their peers (relative to being primed to think about parents. H4: The effect of MCII on absenteeism will be smaller the more self-control students possess. H5: In the long run, we expect similar effects on dropout

q17.value: Power calculation The experiment will contain 3 experimental groups: Treatment 1 (MCII + parents), Treatment 2 (MCII + peers) and a control group. A power calculation shows that conditional on a sample size of 450 that is fairly evenly distributed among the experimental groups that we will be able to detect an effect-size of around 10-15 percentage points change in dropout and absenteeism from the course with a power of 80%. This partly depends on absenteeism and dropout in the control group (estimated with the Stata command: power twoproportions (.25 .50 .75), n(150 300 450) power(.8)). Recruitment and randomization To test the hypotheses, we designed a field experiment which will be carried out among students at the basic level at the vocational schools Aarhus Tech (N = 436) and SOSU Oestjylland (N = 129) in the fall of 2017. This gives us a population size of 565 students. Students will be asked to answer a survey during school time. Not all students will participate, but we expect to have at least 450 respondents as suggested by the power calculation. Treatments will be embedded in the survey. Students will be randomly assigned individually to one of the three experimental conditions when they initiate the survey. We therefore expect little attrition (only students that do not fill out the whole survey and students without follow-up data). The treatment will be a MCII treatment. The specific sequence of the MCII is the following: First respondents are asked about their desired future; their goals. They are asked to imagine this future as vividly as possible, almost like a fantasy, and then mention and elaborate on the outcomes that they associate with this future. Secondly, they are asked to elaborate on the parts of the present reality that might stand in the way of their future goals. They are asked to mention specific obstacles that might interfere with the goals and then to elaborate vividly on these obstacles and how they might interfere. The last part of MCII is the implementation part: writing an if-then plan that is supposed to address the previously mentioned obstacles (Duckworth et al. 2013; Kizilcec and Cohen 2017). Measures The outcome variables will be both short-term self-assessments and longer term objective measures of absence and dropout from the school. The primary outcome measure will be administrative data on the individual students’ absence from school. To study the mechanisms, we will use items embedded in the survey. Right after having received treatments (or control) the students will be asked about their strength of goal pursuit. This is operationalized as energization (“How keen are you on completing your basic course?”), future planning (“To which extent have you made plans on how to complete your basic education?”) and responsibility of reaching desired goals (“To which extent do you determine whether you will reach your goals with the education?”). To study longer-term outcomes, we will obtain administrative data on the dropout at the individual level from the basic part of the vocational educations from the two schools. The moderator variables, future orientation and self-control, will be collected as part of the survey. Operationalization of future orientation will follow the measure (10 items) outlined in Steinberg et al. (2009) and self-control will be the brief measure obtained in Tangney et al. (2004) (both translated into Danish). Pre-analysis plan The plan of analysis is first to apply the difference-in-means estimator via OLS regression to obtain the average intention-to-treat effect of the two MCII treatments (combined) in comparison with the control group (H1). This will be done using the dependent variables strength of goal pursuit (additive index comprising of the 3 above mentioned items) and the absenteeism measure. A logit specification will be used to analyze the dropout measure, since this outcome will be a dummy (dropout or not). Secondly, to test H2 we interact the students’ perceived recognition from their peers with the treatment of being reminded of their peers and include this interaction term in a OLS regression with both of the interacted variables. To test H3 we interact students’ perceived recognition from peers with the treatment of being reminded of their peers and the MCII treatment. This is a three-way-interaction term and it will be analyzed by including it with all two-way interaction terms and variables in the same OLS regression with the 3 outcome measures as dependent variables. We will test hypothesis H4 by interacting the treatment and control groups with an index measure of self-control (Tangney et al. 2004) and include this interaction term in a OLS regression with both of the interacted variables. H5 is tested in the same way as H1-H4 only with dropout as outcome. Since dropout is binary measure and since it is measured over time, a survival analysis will be employed.

registration_responses.q1: The Influence of Social Reference Groups on Behavioral Interventions to Reduce Absenteeism and Dropout from Vocational Education
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities
registration_responses.q15: Dropout and absence is a large problem in vocational training in Denmark which has large societal costs. Many policy reforms have sought to address the problem, e,g., by implementing admission thresholds, restructuring the general program, setting up performance measures for the different educations and supporting the creation of more internships (The Danish Government 2014; Munk et al. 2015). However, few of these reforms directly address the motivation and goals of the students themselves, which has been argued to be a large part of their absence and dropout in vocational educations in Denmark (Katznelson and Brown 2011). In this study we seek to use Mental Contrasting with Implementation Intensions (MCII) as a cost-efficient, psychological way of addressing student absence and dropout from vocational training in Denmark. MCII has been shown to affect goal-directed behavior in various fields and settings, especially in the educational setting (Duckworth et al. 2013; Oettingen et al. 2013; Kizilcec and Cohen 2017). The idea is that it is not always enough to have goals. People need to develop a sense of feasibility of the goal – an expectation of successful goal striving – and a commitment to these goals. However, the goals may still not succeed in creating goal-directed behavior, because we have a tendency not to consider the impeding reality when constructing the goals. MCII seeks to address these pitfalls in creating goal-directed behavior and succeeding in reaching the goals by instructing people to think about both their goals, why they would like to meet them, which obstacles they will probably face along the way and to plan strategies to overcome these. In a way, MCII is a structured way of thinking about goals, a self-regulation strategy, that may more effectively result in goal fulfillment (Oettingen et al. 2013), making it a type of wise psychological intervention (Walton 2014). Furthermore, we will investigate the influence of social image among adolescents when they attend an education. It is well known that adolescents are more susceptible to peer influence than other age groups and they should also still be under the influence of their parents (Steinberg and Monahan 2007; Steinberg 2014). It has been argued that social image is an important influence when adolescents make educational decisions (Bursztyn and Jensen 2015, 2017). We argue that this social image might change with different reference groups, such that adolescents react differently when they are thinking about their parents as opposed to thinking about their peers as reference groups when making decisions. Therefore, our MCII treatment group is divided into two treatment groups where the students are either presented with questions about their parents’ or their peers’ recognition and a question on how important this reference groups’ recognition is to them before being asked the standard MCII questions. Therefore, we are priming the students to think of either their parents or peers and the students’ own perceptions of how much recognition they would get from these reference groups if they completed their basic education. Lastly, we will examine whether the students’ self-control (Tangney et al. 2004) will moderate the effect of MCII on student absence and dropout. Self-control is thought to moderate the effects of MCII, since people high on self-control may already have a tendency to follow through on plans, while people low on self-control may need some help, especially on forming and sticking to the if-then plans (Oettingen et al. 2013). Therefore, we expect that self-control will moderate the effect of MCII such that the effect is largest among students with low self-control.
registration_responses.q16: Primary hypothesis: H1: MCII will reduce absenteeism of all participating students on average Secondary hypotheses: H2: Priming students to think about peers will reduce absence (relative to priming to think about parents) the more recognition from peers they perceive they will get. H3: The more positive recognition students perceive they will get from peers, the more will the effect of MCII be moderated by priming students to think about their peers (relative to being primed to think about parents. H4: The effect of MCII on absenteeism will be smaller the more self-control students possess. H5: In the long run, we expect similar effects on dropout
registration_responses.q17: Power calculation The experiment will contain 3 experimental groups: Treatment 1 (MCII + parents), Treatment 2 (MCII + peers) and a control group. A power calculation shows that conditional on a sample size of 450 that is fairly evenly distributed among the experimental groups that we will be able to detect an effect-size of around 10-15 percentage points change in dropout and absenteeism from the course with a power of 80%. This partly depends on absenteeism and dropout in the control group (estimated with the Stata command: power twoproportions (.25 .50 .75), n(150 300 450) power(.8)). Recruitment and randomization To test the hypotheses, we designed a field experiment which will be carried out among students at the basic level at the vocational schools Aarhus Tech (N = 436) and SOSU Oestjylland (N = 129) in the fall of 2017. This gives us a population size of 565 students. Students will be asked to answer a survey during school time. Not all students will participate, but we expect to have at least 450 respondents as suggested by the power calculation. Treatments will be embedded in the survey. Students will be randomly assigned individually to one of the three experimental conditions when they initiate the survey. We therefore expect little attrition (only students that do not fill out the whole survey and students without follow-up data). The treatment will be a MCII treatment. The specific sequence of the MCII is the following: First respondents are asked about their desired future; their goals. They are asked to imagine this future as vividly as possible, almost like a fantasy, and then mention and elaborate on the outcomes that they associate with this future. Secondly, they are asked to elaborate on the parts of the present reality that might stand in the way of their future goals. They are asked to mention specific obstacles that might interfere with the goals and then to elaborate vividly on these obstacles and how they might interfere. The last part of MCII is the implementation part: writing an if-then plan that is supposed to address the previously mentioned obstacles (Duckworth et al. 2013; Kizilcec and Cohen 2017). Measures The outcome variables will be both short-term self-assessments and longer term objective measures of absence and dropout from the school. The primary outcome measure will be administrative data on the individual students’ absence from school. To study the mechanisms, we will use items embedded in the survey. Right after having received treatments (or control) the students will be asked about their strength of goal pursuit. This is operationalized as energization (“How keen are you on completing your basic course?”), future planning (“To which extent have you made plans on how to complete your basic education?”) and responsibility of reaching desired goals (“To which extent do you determine whether you will reach your goals with the education?”). To study longer-term outcomes, we will obtain administrative data on the dropout at the individual level from the basic part of the vocational educations from the two schools. The moderator variables, future orientation and self-control, will be collected as part of the survey. Operationalization of future orientation will follow the measure (10 items) outlined in Steinberg et al. (2009) and self-control will be the brief measure obtained in Tangney et al. (2004) (both translated into Danish). Pre-analysis plan The plan of analysis is first to apply the difference-in-means estimator via OLS regression to obtain the average intention-to-treat effect of the two MCII treatments (combined) in comparison with the control group (H1). This will be done using the dependent variables strength of goal pursuit (additive index comprising of the 3 above mentioned items) and the absenteeism measure. A logit specification will be used to analyze the dropout measure, since this outcome will be a dummy (dropout or not). Secondly, to test H2 we interact the students’ perceived recognition from their peers with the treatment of being reminded of their peers and include this interaction term in a OLS regression with both of the interacted variables. To test H3 we interact students’ perceived recognition from peers with the treatment of being reminded of their peers and the MCII treatment. This is a three-way-interaction term and it will be analyzed by including it with all two-way interaction terms and variables in the same OLS regression with the 3 outcome measures as dependent variables. We will test hypothesis H4 by interacting the treatment and control groups with an index measure of self-control (Tangney et al. 2004) and include this interaction term in a OLS regression with both of the interacted variables. H5 is tested in the same way as H1-H4 only with dropout as outcome. Since dropout is binary measure and since it is measured over time, a survival analysis will be employed.

attributes.title: Salience of political identity and social attitudes

q1.value: Salience of political identity and social attitudes

q5.value: The research is supported by the grant K 120070 of NKFIH (Hungarian public research funding agency). , Comments by Marcel van Assen and Gabor Hajdu are greatfully acknowledged.

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: A question investigated in the literature: the effects of opinions of political elite groups on voters’ attitudes towards contested policy issues. Three mechanisms are discussed in the literature about elite influence: rational learning, motivated reasoning, and social (political) identity. This latter refers to the direct effect of feelings of affection to a political community. Effects of rational learning and motivated reasoning have been tested extensively. However, it is very hard to single out the independent effect of identity in such studies: predictions based on identity motivation tend to coincide with those based on either rational learning or motivated reasoning. My aim is to construct a test of identity-based political attitude adjustment which excludes the alternative hypotheses based on rational learning or motivated reasoning. I construct an experimental design where (some of) the treatments a) do not provide information for subjects about party positions, b) do not even provide arguments or dilemmas about the issue in focus, but c) manipulate the situational salience of political identity. The major hypothesis is that the increase of situational salience of political identity will lead to attitude adjustment in accordance with perceived group norms (even without providing any information about party postitions). However, this effect of situational salience may disappear if the voter’s baseline identity is extremely strong or extremely weak.

q16.value: H1 The significant increase of salience of political identity, on average, will increase the likelyhood of attitude adjustment in accordance with the perceived position of the voter's preferred political community on a politicized question. H1.1 The increase of salience of political conflict between political communities will, in itself, increase the likelyhood of attitude adjustment in accordance with the perceived position of the voter's preferred political community on the politicized question (even without referring to the issue) H1.2 The increase of salience of perceived moral difference between political communities will, in itself, increase the likelyhood of attitude adjustment in accordance with the perceived position of the voter's preferred political community on the politicized question. H1.3 The increase of salience of perceived differences of typical/expected opinions on a politicized question between political communities will, in itself, increase the likelyhood of attitude adjustment in accordance with the perceived position of the voter's preferred political community on the politicized question. H2 The increase of situational salience of political identity will not increase the likelyhood of attitude adjustment in accordance with the perceived position of the voter's preferred political community on a non-politicized policy question H3 The increase of salience of political identity will not increase the likelyhood of attitude adjustment in accordance with the perceived position of the voter's preferred political community among politically extremely lowly and highly engaged individuals.

q17.value: I increase the salience of political identity in the treatment conditions. I make political identity salient in three ways: 1) I make the political conflict between various political communities salient without mentioning elite/group opinion on or conflict around the question. 2) I make respondent’s judgments on ingroup-outgroup moral differences salient without mentioning elite/group opinions on or conflicts around the question. 3) I make the perceived typical group opinion about the question salient. I present statements about two questions: one of them has been politicized in the months before the survey in Hungary, the other one hasn’t (the benefits of funding Hungarian civil organizations from abroad, and reforms giving voting rights for children).

attributes.title: Comparing Direct and Indirect Localized Peace Enforcement: Evidence from Peacebuilding in Mali

q1.value: Comparing Direct and Indirect Localized Peace Enforcement: Evidence from Peacebuilding in Mali

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The main goal of this project is to test the implications of the theoretical framework outlined in my doctoral dissertation. In particular, the project has two purposes. First, it will complement a previous lab-in-the-field experiment and a survey experiment designed to test the effectiveness of direct localized peace enforcement. Second, building off of a previous survey experiment, it will compare the effectiveness of direct and indirect localized peace enforcement operations.

q16.value: H1: French and UN indirect LPE operations in Mali are equally likely to succeed H2: UN direct LPE operations in Mali are likely to be more effective than French direct LPE operations

q17.value: I will implement a survey experiment in 12 villages in the Malian region of Segou. The survey will be conducted in two stages. In the first stage, enumerators will travel to each of the villages and mobilize 60 respondents/village, collecting their phone numbers in the process. In the second stage, enumerators will call respondents (completing 30 respondents/village) from a central call center in Bamako, the capital of Mali. This is done to maximize the safety of the respondents.

attributes.title: How Public Officeholders Prioritize Learning about Public Opinion

q1.value: How Public Officeholders Prioritize Learning about Public Opinion

q2.value: John McAndrews | Benjamin Allen Stevens | Roosmarijn De Geus | Jonah Goldberg | Md. Mujahedul Islam | Lior Sheffer | Peter Loewen | Daniel Rubenson

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Public officeholders are constantly flooded with policy information from a variety of sources—often much more than they can reasonably be expected to consume. Given this constraint, they must prioritize. The aim of this project is to better understand how public officeholders prioritize what policy information to consume. Here we focus specifically on the consumption of information related to the public’s policy attitudes. The central claim is that public officeholders’ political and social identities inform the groups of individuals they choose to learn about.

q16.value: Participants (i.e., Canadian senators) are invited to participate in a survey in which they could view the results of a separate, previously completed 2015 survey of Canadian citizens. Senators could choose to view the results of the 2015 survey in the following five ways: (1) by vote choice in 2015, (2) by province, (3) by gender, (4) by ethnicity, or (5) by indigenous identity. H1: Senate Conservatives are more likely than independent senators to select the ‘by vote choice in 2015’ view. H2: Senate Liberals are more likely than independent senators to select the ‘by vote choice in 2015’ view. H3: Female senators are more likely than male senators to select the ‘by gender’ view. H4: Non-Ontario senators are more likely than Ontario senators to select the ‘by province’ view. H5: Non-white senators are more likely than white senators to select the ‘by ethnicity’ or ‘by Indigenous identity’ view. Further details can be founded in the attached pre-analysis plan.

q17.value: We will evaluate the hypotheses using one of the following two estimation strategies—depending on the number of observations. If the number of senator-issue observations is greater than or equal to 100, we will use multinomial logit. If the number of senator-issue observations is less than 100, we will use 2 X 2 cross-tabulations and test using either a Pearson’s chi-squared test or a Fisher’s exact test. Further details can be found in the attached pre-analysis plan.

q21.value: We performed preliminary calculations to assess the relative power of various survey designs. Ultimately, however, the # of participants (Cdn senators) is fixed at approx 90. We do not have clear expectations about their participation or dropout rates.

attributes.title: Group cues and political mobilization and salience

q1.value: Group cues and political mobilization and salience

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The evidence of social group influence is mixed. There is correlational evidence in which stronger identifiers of a group more likely hold political attitudes that “match” the group. This is problematic as we don’t know why certain people are strong group identifiers and others aren’t. And if politics or political attitudes helps explain why people identify with certain social groups or if politics help transform social identities into political identities, then correlational estimates do not give us a good sense of social group influence. The experimental data also show mixed evidence of social group influence. In many experiments, social group cues don’t correspond with changes in policy attitudes. This may be that the identities are already aligned. In other words, we may not see group cues shaping attitudes on issues when there is already agreement as there is nowhere to move. Therefore, experiments that look at policy attitudes may not give us a good sense of social group influence. The main research question, therefore, is how might social group influence play a role in a world in which political and social identities are frequently aligned?

q16.value: The experiment will test how individuals who self-identify as part of one of three groups—African Americans, evangelical Christians, and feminists—respond to political cues from their social groups. The three identities represent three social identities that may be consequential for politics and vary is just how “sticky” they are. Moreover, the three identities are closely aligned with one of the two main political parties: white evangelicals are disproportionately Republicans while feminists and African Americans are disproportionately Republicans. Given how closely aligned these social and political identities are, the first main hypothesis of the experiment is that a social group cue does not have an effect on reported attitudes. Instead, when group identities and political attitudes are aligned, social group’s influence is more likely to be seen in their ability to mobilize. As such, the second main hypothesis of the experiment is that a social group cue can impact a group member’s willingness to act politically on the issue at hand and likelihood of reporting that the issue is an important issue. When group members already hold attitudes that are consistent with the social group's position, group influence is seen through increased salience and mobilization. Conversely, social group cues should demobilize group members when identities and attitudes are not aligned (This hypothesis may be difficult to empirically test as it will depend on how many group members hold unaligned identities and attitudes). Identity strength is a potential moderator that may be interacted with the treatment. From this, two additional hypotheses emerge. First, identity strength should not be a moderator that affects how group identifiers respond to the treatment when the dependent variable is issue positions. While strong group identifiers may be more likely to respond to the treatment, there may be no room for movement as strong identifiers are the most likely to already hold the group's position. Second, identity strength should be a moderator that affects how group identifiers respond to the treatment when the dependent variable is mobilization and issue salience. The nature of the current political environment lends itself to a few additional hypotheses that can be explored using these data. In particular, there is a literature that notes non-religious people using evangelicalism as a negative cue (see Adkins et al. 2013; Bolce and De Main 1999). As such, an additional hypothesis is that religious non-identifiers who receive the evangelical cue may respond in the opposite direction of the cue (that is, take a more liberal position) compared to non-evangelicals in the control condition (hypothesis from existing research). It is also possible, however, that religious non-identifiers also take a sufficiently unified liberal position that the evangelical group cue does not produce a detectable effect on policy attitudes (alternative hypothesis). Drawing on the same anti-evangelical literature, religious non-identifiers who hold liberal policy positions on issues in question and receive the evangelical cue should be more likely to mobilize around the policy issue--in the opposite direction of the evangelical cue--than the religious non-identifiers who do not receive the evangelical cue. It is possible that the same backlash may exist among non-feminists who receive the feminist treatment; however, there is not empirical evidence showing that non-feminists respond negatively to feminism although there is reason to suspect it may be a possibility.

q17.value: The hypotheses will be tested using straightforward methods. First, respondents will be separated into groups based on their identities which are determined prior to randomization into the treatment conditions. Second, difference-in-means tests for four dependent variables (issue attitude, willingness to attend a city council meeting, reported salience of the issue, and desire for more information) comparing respondents who received the treatment and control versions of the experiment will be analyzed within each of the three identity groups. Third, for the models that use identity strength as a moderator, the treatment indicator will be interacted with the measure of identity strength.

registration_responses.q1: Group cues and political mobilization and salience
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

There is correlational evidence in which stronger identifiers of a group more likely hold political attitudes that “match” the group. This is problematic as we don’t know why certain people are strong group identifiers and others aren’t. And if politics or political attitudes helps explain why people identify with certain social groups or if politics help transform social identities into political identities, then correlational estimates do not give us a good sense of social group influence. The experimental data also show mixed evidence of social group influence. In many experiments, social group cues don’t correspond with changes in policy attitudes. This may be that the identities are already aligned. In other words, we may not see group cues shaping attitudes on issues when there is already agreement as there is nowhere to move. Therefore, experiments that look at policy attitudes may not give us a good sense of social group influence. The main research question, therefore, is how might social group influence play a role in a world in which political and social identities are frequently aligned?

Conversely, social group cues should demobilize group members when identities and attitudes are not aligned (This hypothesis may be difficult to empirically test as it will depend on how many group members hold unaligned identities and attitudes). Identity strength is a potential moderator that may be interacted with the treatment. From this, two additional hypotheses emerge. First, identity strength should not be a moderator that affects how group identifiers respond to the treatment when the dependent variable is issue positions. While strong group identifiers may be more likely to respond to the treatment, there may be no room for movement as strong identifiers are the most likely to already hold the group's position. Second, identity strength should be a moderator that affects how group identifiers respond to the treatment when the dependent variable is mobilization and issue salience. The nature of the current political environment lends itself to a few additional hypotheses that can be explored using these data. In particular, there is a literature that notes non-religious people using evangelicalism as a negative cue (see Adkins et al. 2013; Bolce and De Main 1999). As such, an additional hypothesis is that religious non-identifiers who receive the evangelical cue may respond in the opposite direction of the cue (that is, take a more liberal position) compared to non-evangelicals in the control condition (hypothesis from existing research). It is also possible, however, that religious non-identifiers also take a sufficiently unified liberal position that the evangelical group cue does not produce a detectable effect on policy attitudes (alternative hypothesis). Drawing on the same anti-evangelical literature, religious non-identifiers who hold liberal policy positions on issues in question and receive the evangelical cue should be more likely to mobilize around the policy issue--in the opposite direction of the evangelical cue--than the religious non-identifiers who do not receive the evangelical cue. It is possible that the same backlash may exist among non-feminists who receive the feminist treatment; however, there is not empirical evidence showing that non-feminists respond negatively to feminism although there is reason to suspect it may be a possibility.
registration_responses.q17: The hypotheses will be tested using straightforward methods. First, respondents will be separated into groups based on their identities which are determined prior to randomization into the treatment conditions. Second, difference-in-means tests for four dependent variables (issue attitude, willingness to attend a city council meeting, reported salience of the issue, and desire for more information) comparing respondents who received the treatment and control versions of the experiment will be analyzed within each of the three identity groups. Third, for the models that use identity strength as a moderator, the treatment indicator will be interacted with the measure of identity strength.
